I like Crash Course and this Economics course is great. Now, I am saddened by the fact that economists always seem the autistic kid within the Social Sciences. They only read and cite other economists, and keep doing research in areas where good theories and established empirical findings are already in place... not just in psychology (which would be the only thing behavioural economists would cite) but in sociology, political science, anthropology and so on. And hence economists keep asking research questions with a sense of wonder and ingenuity as if no one had ever asked them before. The field of happiness is a painful example of it. I would love a Crash Course in Economics that remains humble in that other social sciences can also help answer this type of social questions.
Thank you CrashCourse For this series. It's the first time I've ever actually felt like I understand economics!
Adore the videos! Will there be one on Neoliberalism? Oh please oh please!

It was a good intro to economics. But it's very left leaning at times. Not that that's a hidden factor on this channel but it does make some of these videos very one-sided and the counter arguments are very often forgotten and ignored. There are some bad psychology mixed into some of these videos and both of these teachers seemed to just adore using psychology to explain economics. While themselves not really understanding psychology or how studies in psychology are done and what they imply. Their points from psychology were mostly wishful thinking and left leaning biased indoctrination. Too often a final point was started by "You should not...", "You should...", "But I feel...".

Again, it's very much worth a watch for people who don't already study economics but please don't take this as gospel. Economics is not supposed to be left or right leaning. And a lecture series where all slightly right leaning study results are apologized for is not really a fantastic lecture series unless you are super critical while you watch it or watch another series that is more neutral right afterwards. While this one was a series with a left leaning view on economics. Milton Friedman has a series with a libertarian view on economics. The same principles are talked about but the conclusions are not completely the same. I would probably suggest people to watch that series to see what I mean. Both this one and the Milton Friedman series are very much biased but very informative if you start to understand when they stop talking about science and start talking about their personal ideas of the world.

It seems rather obvious that all of this data, when taken as a whole, leads to the conclusion that status and money are not independent factors, rather; that they are directly related to the amount one has to serve the desires of others, as a function of time spent on self-determined activities.
If you choose to make a cake for a loved one, your time is spent in a way of your own choosing, for the benefit of another. Contrary to this, if the majority of one's time is spent on a job that has no meaning to your life, say working in a packaging facility for objects that you don't actually get to enjoy, your time is spent making somebody else's life richer, most often your boss, executives and investors, who perceptively do less work yet reap more rewards for their time.
This dynamic means that it is servitude that is the measure of happiness, not any indicator of raw wealth and becomes more prevalent when *status is derived from the ability to acquire the services of others, i.e. items denoting monetary wealth.
This is why the true measure of the success of an economy should be a reduction of income inequality. Less time spent as a servant equates to happier people. Obvious.

Economists are puzzled by happiness vs income because they're so far down their rabbit hole they forget what money is. Of course having more money doesn't make you happier when everyone else has more too, because money doesn't mean anything by itself. It's just accounting. The point of money is it represents power over other people. If you have money you can get them to make things and do things for you. If they also have money they're not interested in that anymore. Then you just have bits of paper, or worse, numbers on a screen.

$82k matters less than you think when you live in about the most expensive place in the US. And guess where you get paid $82k most easily.

Jesus, why isn't there a single word on how "happiness" or "well-being" is measured ? That's the key to understand why there's so much theories and sometimes contradictory studies. I also insist on the quotation marks : how do you even define "happiness" or "well-being" ? In terms of material needs fulfilled ? Then what needs ? Everybody sees it differently depending on your culture, your class, etc. In addition the two concepts are not the same thing. There's a lot more to say but that's not my point. I think it is irresponsible to pretend having a reflection on such a thorny issue without methodological questionings. It's the epistemology, stupid.

Even Simon Kuznets, the inventor of the GDP metric, cautioned against using it as a metric for how 'successful' or healthy a country is, as it doesn't measure well being of the most important part:  the populous.  :)  Great ending quote to this episode and this series.  There's nothing inherent about the economy, it's a human invented thing.  There is no physical or natural force in the universe called the economy.  If the economy is not serving us as human kind, then we can tweak it and alter it.  It should serve us, not the other way around.  I like the idea of Gross Domestic Happiness, or Gross Domestic Well Being.  That which makes us grow and live and love and laugh and enjoy and swoon is what matters.  :)

The thing with the birthday dinner, that's in psychology, too. I forget what it was called, exactly, but it was used with the example of a child reading because he/she enjoys it. If a parent offered to pay or reward the child, they were less likely to enjoy reading as much as they did, decreasing with the attempt to reinforce the behaviour. It proved that intrinsic motivation can be affected by extrinsic motivation; in this case negatively

What does the relative value of happiness in people's lives imply about the significance of the gender "wage gap"?
(I'm talking here about the wage gap which STILL exists in countries which have mandated maternity/paternity leave. The US has a long way to go to meet the Nordic standard.)
Might women, as a group, place more importance on quality of life than quantity of salary?
Much of the "controversy" of the gap can be chalked up to women judging their status by men's priorities.
It is the men who might benefit emotionally from sacrificing salary, rather than the women who would benefit materially from increased salary.
(I keep editing to make my point clearer ... less emphasis on money only has a chance of working in a society that has strong progressive tax structure, to keep the predators from hoarding the means of living.)

I think we all have our own 'source' of happiness. We are happy when we do something we like and if we spending most time in our life doing things we like, we will have happy life.

However, we have one common source of happiness: we'll feeling good (or 'happy') when we know/feel that we are 'better' than our neighbors or friends. No matter how poor or miserable, as long as you believe that you are better off than those around you, you will feel good about yourself. That same thing happen to the rich too.

"Economic thought over the last couple of centuries [is built on the premise] that more equals better".
I would say that is a pretty one-sided and typically American lecture of economic history. There has been countless critics of it for as long as capitalism has existed.
"People are happier with their jobs more than can be explained in terms of the money they are paid"
Duh. People enjoy working on things they are good at because it increases one's self-worth, skills and status. Earth to America: people have been surviving without money for 200.000 years just fine. Most people on the planet don't value money nearly as much as Americans assume, as long as they have enough to go by. That I have to explain this to any adult makes me sad.

Meh... I don't really feel there is an understanding of happiness had by these economists... Some theories were based on fallacies, while other theories were just too shallow. (e.g., unemployed people aren't only worried about money, but about purpose in life, they lost part of their identity if fired, there is the anxiety cause by change, many complain about losing their sense of time, etc...)

More money doesn't necessarily make one happier. Money is just a tool to accomplish your goals. A poor person able to accomplish his goals can be quite happy, even more-so than an extremely wealthy person who sacrificed for money. (I know I am far happier losing thousands and getting to stay around my family than I would be if I abandoned them for money.)

actually if you look Maslow pyramid of needs the 4th tier (esteem) is one which can be very easily be achieved though working. completing the tasks at work gives a sense of accomplishment needed for this tier. the contact whit colleagues plays into the 3rd tier (social interactions) the bottom 2 tiers (safety and biological) can be bought. once the bottom 2 are bought more money wont make you happier. the 5th and top tier is Self Actualization and where you are perfectly happy!

this explains both why there is a ceiling on the amount of money earned in relation to happiness and why losing a job affect you more than just je loss of the money. remember the 3rd tier is also fed by social interactions whit friends and family that you are not getting while commuting and working 24/7.

There's a reason why it was written as "the PURSUIT of happiness." Happiness itself, is nice, but if it's your goal you soon find out you get into a lot of trouble.

First, it would be easy to make everyone happy. Just get them completely buzzed off of opium for the rest of their days. Happiness solved. Or you could do it in a more "natural" way by just living in a stagnant commune structure and never really changing.

Until you are FORCED to, but an outside effect that wipes you out or nearly does so. Our advancement and progress have allowed us to avoid a ton of these.

So our continued living, progress and our actions towards happiness are what is important. NOT happiness itself.
In other words, people are approval junkies, they need other people to be poor in order to feel good about themselves.

"In the U.S., the pursuit of happiness is one of our inalienable rights, written into our Declaration of Independence right along with the biggies, life and liberty!"

So which is it? Inalienable, or requiring a qualifier such as, "in the U.S."?

Reading the Declaration of Independence, it's clear that Jefferson wasn't writing to create or enshrine some opinion about what individual rights should be, but to point out that these inalienable rights are inherent to our natures, and went so far as to call this a self-evident truth. That means these inalienable rights are not just inalienable in the U.S., and they didn't start being inalienable when the Declaration of Independence was written or adopted. They are inalienable for every person who has ever lived, who now lives, or who will ever live. It's in that list next to life and liberty because it's also a biggie on its own.

Adding the qualifier is not only unnecessary, it weakens the entire concept of rights.
The pursuit of happiness is a farce in the American Society we have built.
